author: marianna_metrika
content: thanks for the prompt reply, I think I was a bit confused with the fact that you can't forward sync from before the blob availability window and somehow assumed that if you were to spin up a new node this would affect syncing from genesis

author: pawandhananjay
content: we can't  guarantee that the blobs outside the availability window would be available over p2p. so if we genesis sync, we have to assume that they were available at that time

author: marianna_metrika
content: right, so this applies to blobs only though, correct? we can still fetch all the blocks

author: tersec
content: In practice probably, but `MIN_EPOCHS_FOR_BLOCK_REQUESTS` (https://github.com/ethereum/consensus-specs/blob/dev/specs/phase0/p2p-interface.md#configuration) is still only 5 months.

author: tersec
content: even pre-Dencun, in theory genesis sync isn't really "supported", right now

author: 0xevan
content:
hey I was looking at blob transactions here from dencun - https://blobscan.com/txs

* I thought per EIP-4844 the max blob size is 125kb not 128kb?
* is it possible to submit a blob with less than the max size? For instance if I was a rollup, could I submit a blob with 25kb sie?

author: marianna_metrika
content: I think all blobs are padded with zeros so that they are always 128kb

author: 0xevan
content: Is this a requirement for blobs to be submitted then? Or is this just for testnet purposes

author: tersec
content: https://eips.ethereum.org/EIPS/eip-4844 defines a blob as `ByteVector[BYTES_PER_FIELD_ELEMENT * FIELD_ELEMENTS_PER_BLOB]` i.e. 32 * 4096 = 131072 bytes. This is 128KiB (kibibits, the base 2 version). https://github.com/ethereum/consensus-specs/blob/dev/specs/deneb/polynomial-commitments.md#constants similarly defines `BYTES_PER_BLOB` as `uint64(BYTES_PER_FIELD_ELEMENT * FIELD_ELEMENTS_PER_BLOB)` which also is 131,072 bytes for the same reason.
